verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 13:13
verses.text: It is said that his mother was killed by the same stroke, and it was only right that she, who had bestowed so dangerous a beast on the world, should escape to heaven by the same ladder.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 13:14
verses.text: And yet the Athenians will not be at a loss how to sacrifice to gods of such a fashion, for they pay divine honours to aesculapius and his mother amongst their dead (worthies).

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 13:15
verses.text: As if, too, they had not ready to hand their own Theseus to worship, so highly deserving a god's distinction! Well, why not? Did he not on a foreign shore abandon the preserver of his life, with the same indifference, nay heartlessness, with which he became the cause of his father's death?.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:1
verses.text: The Constellations and the Genii Very Indifferent Gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:2
verses.text: The Roman Monopoly of Gods Unsatisfactory.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:3
verses.text: Other Nations Require Deities Quite as Much.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:4
verses.text: It would be tedious to take a survey of all those, too, whom you have buried amongst the constellations, and audaciously minister to as gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:5
verses.text: I suppose your Castors, and Perseus, and Erigona, have just the same claims for the honours of the sky as Jupiter's own big boy had.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:6
verses.text: But why should we wonder? You have transferred to heaven even dogs, and scorpions, and crabs.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:7
verses.text: I postpone all remarks concerning those whom you worship in your oracles.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:8
verses.text: That this worship exists, is attested by him who pronounces the oracle.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:9
verses.text: Why; you will have your gods to be spectators even of sadness, as is Viduus, who makes a widow of the soul, by parting it from the body, and whom you have condemned, by not permitting him to be enclosed within your city-walls; there is Caeculus also, to deprive the eyes of their perception; and Orbana, to bereave seed of its vital power; moreover, there is the goddess of death herself.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:10
verses.text: To pass hastily by all others, you account as gods the sites of places or of the city; such are Father Janus (there being, moreover, the archer-goddess Jana), and Septimontius of the seven hills.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:11
verses.text: Men sacrifice to the same Genii, whilst they have altars or temples in the same places; but to others besides, when they dwell in a strange place, or live in rented houses.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:12
verses.text: I say nothing about Ascensus, who gets his name for his climbing propensity, and Clivicola, from her sloping (haunts); I pass silently by the deities called Forculus from doors, and Cardea from hinges, and Limentinus the god of thresholds, and whatever others are worshipped by your neighbours as tutelar deities of their street doors.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:13
verses.text: There is nothing strange in this, since men have their respective gods in their brothels, their kitchens, and even in their prison.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:14
verses.text: Heaven, therefore, is crowded with innumerable gods of its own, both these and others belonging to the Romans, which have distributed amongst them the functions of one's whole life, in such a way that there is no want of the other gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 14:15
verses.text: Although, it is true, the gods which we have enumerated are reckoned as Roman peculiarly, and as not easily recognised abroad; yet how do all those functions and circumstances, over which men have willed their gods to preside, come about, in every part of the human race, and in every nation, where their guarantees are not only without an official recognition, but even any recognition at all?.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:1
verses.text: Inventors of Useful Arts Unworthy of Deification.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:2
verses.text: They Would Be the First to Acknowledge a Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:3
verses.text: The Arts Changeable from Time to Time, and Some Become Obsolete.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:4
verses.text: Well, but certain men have discovered fruits and sundry necessaries of life, (and hence are worthy of deification).

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:5
verses.text: Now let me ask, when you call these persons "discoverers," do you not confess that what they discovered was already in existence? Why then do you not prefer to honour the Author, from whom the gifts really come, instead of converting the Author into mere discoverers? Previously he who made the discover, the inventor himself no doubt expressed his gratitude to the Author; no doubt, too, he felt that He was God, to whom really belonged the religious service, as the Creator (of the gift), by whom also both he who discovered and that which was discovered were alike created.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:6
verses.text: The green fig of Africa nobody at Rome had heard of when Cato introduced it to the Senate, in order that he might show how near was that province of the enemy whose subjugation he was constantly urging.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:7
verses.text: The cherry was first made common in Italy by Cn.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:8
verses.text: Pompey, who imported it from Pontus.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:9
verses.text: I might possibly have thought the earliest introducers of apples amongst the Romans deserving of the public honour of deification.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:10
verses.text: This, however, would be as foolish a ground for making gods as even the invention of the useful arts.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 15:11
verses.text: And yet if the skilful men of our own time be compared with these, how much more suitable would deification be to the later generation than to the former! For, tell me, have not all the extant inventions superseded antiquity, whilst daily experience goes on adding to the new stock? Those, therefore, whom you regard as divine because of their arts, you are really injuring by your very arts, and challenging (their divinity) by means of rival attainments, which cannot be surpassed.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:1
verses.text: Conclusion, the Romans Owe Not Their Imperial Power to Their Gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:2
verses.text: The Great God Alone Dispenses Kingdoms, He is the God of the Christians.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:3
verses.text: In conclusion, without denying all those whom antiquity willed and posterity has believed to be gods, to be the guardians of your religion, there yet remains for our consideration that very large assumption of the Roman superstitions which we have to meet in opposition to you, O heathen, viz.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:4
verses.text: that the Romans have become the lords and masters of the whole world, because by their religious offices they have merited this dominion to such an extent that they are within a very little of excelling even their own gods in power.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:5
verses.text: One cannot wonder that Sterculus, and Mutunus, and Larentina, have severally advanced this empire to its height! The Roman people has been by its gods alone ordained to such dominion.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:6
verses.text: For I could not imagine that any foreign gods would have preferred doing more for a strange nation than for their own people, and so by such conduct become the deserters and neglecters, nay, the betrayers of the native land wherein they were born and bred, and ennobled and buried.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:7
verses.text: Thus not even Jupiter could suffer his own Crete to be subdued by the Roman fasces, forgetting that cave of Ida, and the brazen cymbals of the Corybantes, and the most pleasant odour of the goat which nursed him on that dear spot.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:8
verses.text: Would he not have made that tomb of his superior to the whole Capitol, so that that land should most widely rule which covered the ashes of Jupiter?  Would Juno, too, be willing that the Punic city, for the love of which she even neglected Samos, should be destroyed, and that, too, by the fires of the sons of aeneas? Although I am well aware that  "Hic illius arma,  Hic currus fuit, hoc regnum des gentibus esse,  Si qua fata sinant, jam tunc tenditque fovetque".

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:9
verses.text: "Here were her arms, her chariot here,  Here goddess-like, to fix one day  The seat of universal sway,  Might fate be wrung to yield assent,  E'en then her schemes, her cares were bent".

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:10
verses.text: Still the unhappy (queen of gods) had no power against the fates! And yet the Romans did not accord as much honour to the fates, although they gave them Carthage, as they did to Larentina.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:11
verses.text: But surely those gods of yours have not the power of conferring empire.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:12
verses.text: For when Jupiter reigned in Crete, and Saturn in Italy, and Isis in Egypt, it was even as men that they reigned, to whom also were assigned many to assist them.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:13
verses.text: Thus he who serves also makes masters, and the bond-slave of Admetus aggrandizes with empire the citizens of Rome, although he destroyed his own liberal votary Croesus by deceiving him with ambiguous oracles.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:14
verses.text: Being a god, why was he afraid boldly to foretell to him the truth that he must lose his kingdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:15
verses.text: Surely those who were aggrandized with the power of wielding empire might always have been able to keep an eye, as it were, on their own cities.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:16
verses.text: If they were strong enough to confer empire on the Romans, why did not Minerva defend Athens from Xerxes? Or why did not Apollo rescue Delphi out of the hand of Pyrrhus? They who lost their own cities preserve the city of Rome, since (forsooth) the religiousness of Rome has merited the protection! But is it not rather the fact that this excessive devotion has been devised since the empire has attained its glory by the increase of its power? No doubt sacred rites were introduced by Numa, but then your proceedings were not marred by a religion of idols and temples.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:17
verses.text: Piety was simple, and worship humble; altars were artlessly reared, and the vessels (thereof) plain, and the incense from them scant, and the god himself nowhere.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:18
verses.text: Men therefore were not religious before they achieved greatness, (nor great) because they were religious.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:19
verses.text: But how can the Romans possibly seem to have acquired their empire by an excessive religiousness and very profound respect for the gods, when that empire was rather increased after the gods had been slighted? Now, if I am not mistaken, every kingdom or empire is acquired and enlarged by wars, whilst they and their gods also are injured by conquerors.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:20
verses.text: For the same ruin affects both city-walls and temples; similar is the carnage both of civilians and of priests; identical the plunder of profane things and of sacred.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:21
verses.text: To the Romans belong as many sacrileges as trophies; and then as many triumphs over gods as over nations.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:22
verses.text: Still remaining are their captive idols amongst them; and certainly, if they can only see their conquerors, they do not give them their love.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:23
verses.text: Since, however, they have no perception, they are injured with impunity; and since they are injured with impunity, they are worshipped to no purpose.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:24
verses.text: The nation, therefore, which has grown to its powerful height by victory after victory, cannot seem to have developed owing to the merits of its religion—whether they have injured the religion by augmenting their power, or augmented their power by injuring the religion.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:25
verses.text: All nations have possessed empire, each in its proper time, as the Assyrians, the Medes, the Persians, the Egyptians; empire is even now also in the possession of some, and yet they that have lost their power used not to behave without attention to religious services and the worship of the gods, even after these had become unpropitious to them, until at last almost universal dominion has accrued to the Romans.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:26
verses.text: It is the fortune of the times that has thus constantly shaken kingdoms with revolution.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:27
verses.text: Inquire who has ordained these changes in the times.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:28
verses.text: It is the same (great Being) who dispenses kingdoms, and has now put the supremacy of them into the hands of the Romans, very much as if the tribute of many nations were after its exaction amassed in one (vast) coffer.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 16:29
verses.text: What He has determined concerning it, they know who are the nearest to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:1
verses.text: A Fragment Concerning the Execrable Gods of the Heathen.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:2
verses.text: So great blindness has fallen on the Roman race, that they call their enemy Lord, and preach the filcher of blessings as being their very giver, and to him they give thanks.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:3
verses.text: They call those (deities), then, by human names, not by their own, for their own names they know not.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:4
verses.text: That they are daemons they understand: but they read histories of the old kings, and then, though they see that their character was mortal, they honour them with a deific name.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:5
verses.text: As for him whom they call Jupiter, and think to be the highest god, when he was born the years (that had elapsed) from the foundation of the world to him were some three thousand.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:6
verses.text: He is born in Greece, from Saturnus and Ops; and, for fear he should be killed by his father (or else, if it is lawful to say so, should be begotten anew), is by the advice of his mother carried down into Crete, and reared in a cave of Ida; is concealed from his father's search) by (the aid of) Cretans—born men!—rattling their arms; sucks a she-goat's dugs; flays her; clothes himself in her hide; and (thus) uses his own nurse's hide, after killing her, to be sure, with his own hand! but he sewed thereon three golden tassels worth the price of an hundred oxen each, as their author Homer relates, if it is fair to believe it.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:7
verses.text: This Jupiter, in adult age, waged war several years with his father; overcame him; made a parricidal raid on his home; violated his virgin sisters; selected one of them in marriage; drave his father by dint of arms.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:8
verses.text: The remaining scenes, moreover, of that act have been recorded.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:9
verses.text: Of other folks' wives, or else of violated virgins, he begat him sons; defiled freeborn boys; oppressed peoples lawlessly with despotic and kingly sway.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:10
verses.text: The father, whom they erringly suppose to have been the original god, was ignorant that this (son of his) was lying concealed in Crete; the son, again, whom they believe the mightier god, knows not that the father whom himself had banished is lurking in Italy.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:11
verses.text: If he was in heaven, when would he not see what was doing in Italy? For the Italian land is "not in a corner".

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:12
verses.text: And yet, had he been a god, nothing ought to have escaped him.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:13
verses.text: But that he whom the Italians call Saturnus did lurk there, is clearly evidenced on the face of it, from the fact that from his lurking the Hesperian tongue is to this day called Latin, as likewise their author Virgil relates.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:14
verses.text: (Jupiter,) then, is said to have been born on earth, while (Saturnus his father) fears lest he be driven by him from his kingdom, and seeks to kill him as being his own rival, and knows not that he has been stealthily carried off, and is in hiding; and afterwards the son-god pursues his father, immortal seeks to slay immortal (is it credible?), and is disappointed by an interval of sea, and is ignorant of (his quarry's) flight; and while all this is going on between two gods on earth, heaven is deserted.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:15
verses.text: No one dispensed the rains, no one thundered, no one governed all this mass of world.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:16
verses.text: For they cannot even say that their action and wars took place in heaven; for all this was going on on Mount Olympus in Greece.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:17
verses.text: Well, but heaven is not called Olympus, for heaven is heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:18
verses.text: These, then, are the actions of theirs, which we will treat of first—nativity, lurking, ignorance, parricide, adulteries, obscenities—things committed not by a god, but by most impure and truculent human beings; beings who, had they been living in these days, would have lain under the impeachment of all laws—laws which are far more just and strict than their actions.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:19
verses.text: "He drave his father by dint of arms".

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:20
verses.text: The Falcidian and Sempronian law would bind the parricide in a sack with beasts.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:21
verses.text: "He violated his sisters".

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:22
verses.text: The Papinian law would punish the outrage with all penalties, limb by limb.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:23
verses.text: "He invaded others' wedlock".

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:24
verses.text: The Julian law would visit its adulterous violator capitally.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:25
verses.text: "He defiled freeborn boys".

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:26
verses.text: The Cornelian law would condemn the crime of transgressing the sexual bond with novel severities, sacrilegiously guilty as it is of a novel union.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:27
verses.text: This being is shown to have had no divinity either, for he was a human being; his father's flight escaped him.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:28
verses.text: To this human being, of such a character, to so wicked a king, so obscene and so cruel, God's honour has been assigned by men.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:29
verses.text: Now, to be sure, if on earth he were born and grew up through the advancing stages of life's periods, and in it committed all these evils, and yet is no more in it, what is thought (of him) but that he is dead? Or else does foolish error think wings were born him in his old age, whence to fly heavenward? Why, even this may possibly find credit among men bereft of sense, if indeed they believe, (as they do,) that he turned into a swan, to beget the Castors; an eagle, to contaminate Ganymede; a bull, to violate Europa; gold, to violate Danaë; a horse, to beget Pirithoüs; a goat, to beget Egyppa from a she-goat; a Satyr, to embrace Antiope.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:30
verses.text: Beholding these adulteries, to which sinners are prone, they therefore easily believe that sanctions of misdeed and of every filthiness are borrowed from their feigned god.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:31
verses.text: Do they perceive how void of amendment are the rest of his career's acts which can find credit, which are indeed true, and which, they say, he did without self transformation? Of Semele, he begets Liber; of Latona, Apollo and Diana; of Maia, Mercury; of Alcmena, Hercules.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:32
verses.text: But the rest of his corruptions, which they themselves confess, I am unwilling to record, lest turpitude, once buried, be again called to men's ears.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:33
verses.text: But of these few (offsprings of his) I have made mention; off-springs whom in their error they believe to be themselves, too, gods—born, to wit, of an incestuous father; adulterous births, supposititious births.

verses.name: Tertullian: The Heathen Gods 17:34
verses.text: And the living, eternal God, of sempiternal divinity, prescient of futurity, immeasurable, they have dissipated (into nothing, by associating Him) with crimes so unspeakable.
